comments.commentBody:
The statement of John Gardner that you have provided as a quote is truly the most salient one available to us in this particular forum.

It would have been far more important, as well as more interesting, if Brooks had elaborated on this very insightful statement and thoughtful conjecture put forward by Secretary Gardner.
John Gardner was indeed prescient, was he not.

We do indeed "need one another" and the sooner we all come to this necessary realization, the sooner we will be on the road to a totally successful society that considers the Common Good in all instances and for all persons in our present society.

The goals of social and economic justice were certainly the goals of Secretary Gardner in more than one venue, as exhibited by his lifetime work and his societal attitudes.

Would that today's prominent Republican politicians, their corporate handmaidens, and the dominant 1% all thought in a similar fashion and were as capable of such insightful thinking regarding the future of our country - as was this very noteworthy Republican of another era.

Here's a very meaningful quote from Hubert Humphrey: It was once said that the moral test of government is how that government treats those who are in the dawn of life, the children; those who are in the twilight of life, the elderly; and those who are in the shadows of life, the sick, the needy and the handicapped.
Read more at http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/authors/h/hubert_h_humphrey.html#Pwkw2...

I think our current government has a long, long way to go. And, if the conservatives, the evangelical Christians, the Tea Party, the Democrats, the Republicans, etc., don't think of that as a meaningful statement or a meaningful way to look at things or treat citizens, we have some really huge problems in America.

in reply to several Commenters:

I doubt that John Gardner would have thought the de rigeur poke-in-the-eye to David Brooks by many Commenters, regardless of what he writes, is a good example of demonstrating how we need one another. To the contrary, engaging with those we disagree with is productive in a way that Gardner, I expect, would have advocated.

If Mark Thomason, Mary Scott, and I were not readers of Brooks and took him seriously, I for one would not have had the opportunity to be enlightened by Mary's comment expanding on Mark's comment.

I love learning, and one of the things I have learned is that I do not learn from people who think the same as I do but, rather, from those who think differently.

"You learn not to engage in self-destructive behavior. You learn not to burn up energy in anxiety. You discover how to manage your tensions. You learn that self-pity and resentment are among the most toxic of drugs. You find that the world loves talent but pays off on character."

Those are some fine thoughts, important truths.

I've rarely met anyone who understands all of them, or even very many of them. I've never met anyone who puts them all into practice. I doubt the speaker did. But they are true.

I resolve to try to teach these to my kids now, before they need them.
I don't know about him. I wondered. I wrote in my Diary that she looked different.
Deblasio has to decide, what does he want.  Does he want arrests for low level crimes or not, and then communicate it.

If you want to protest, you have to leave work just like me. I'd use vacation if possible, but I would not collect regular pay for protesting my job. They are doing this while collecting taxpayer funded paychecks. It is quite a different matter. They can exercise their rights the same as all the other citizens. What is happening here is insubordination, not protest. Leaders of this need to be fired and stripped of their pension benefits.

this situation was the creation of the Liberal Democrats who ran the city back in the 1960's through the 1980's - they caved in to most union demands and for their thirst for power- to shut down the city and scare everyone into giving them what they wanted.... now look , a liberal mayor scared stiff by a union his past brethren propped up.
And it shows us exactly how much more we spend on policing than we need too.

Larry - first, do you actually believe that the politicians, who are dependent upon the proportionally larger population of elders, will allow SS to fail? The AARP would have the hide of anyone who voted against continuing it, and they are one of the most effective lobbying fronts in existence today.

Second, if by northeast you mean NYC, Boston, or Washington, you may be right about costs. Here in Western NY, I suspect the cost of living is considerably less even than Dallas. By moving 20 miles north, from Buffalo to Niagara Falls, I have a one bedroom apartment on the river for under $700 per month, including heat. A quick check of Dallas rentals finds few in that range.

I propose that those who come after me repeat my experience by looking logically at needs vs wants, the same as I did, and finding ways to meet the former by dropping some of the latter.

This quiet insurrection is intolerable. The police are daring the Mayor to fire them. If he wobbles or backs down, they will torment him for the rest of his term, if not drive him from office.

If regulations prevent him from firing them outright, he should cease paying them or cut their pay sharply. No employer would tolerate employees who shirk to this extent.

If these prescriptions sound Reaganesque, so be it.

@pat---these were "perceived" by the cops. DeBlasio said NOTHING to get them so riled..besides having a black wife and black children.

These guys aren't the sharpest knives in the world! They got civil service jobs so they can get a full pension, health insurance,and it obviously takes a LOT to get fired.

the liberal democrats who ran the city during the 1960's and 70's created this mess, giving the unions all that they wanted, especially the NYPD... now, it has come back to haunt them.. the PBA will never give up what they gained over the years, only the State legislature can take it away and they never will.

Don't kid yourself, they're still shaking people down. I know several individuals, good people, who have had their small businesses shook down by police. One person I knew who ran a venue had a hidden buzzer he would ring to let the staff know that the cops had arrived to give them time to hide all the money before the police could take it. They would do this at least once a month. Eventually he had to close down, he couldn't afford the losses. Another friend is often forced to give them free food and drink at his restaurant in turn for "protection." The protect & serve.

The frightening thing here is how the police can act independently of their rank and file system. Does the union really have the authority here or do the public officials ? How easily we could return to the bad old days of the 60's-80's when the police regularly took bribe money, committed crimes, harassed minority communities, shook down the gay community etc. This type of independent power is something to be very concerned about. What if the army turned its back on the President ?

There's a lot of great officers out there. To them, I say "thank you for your service and your bravery." To the small but significant number of officers who are acting disrespectfully, while in uniform, and participating in this obvious job action - you should be ashamed of yourselves. Is this what you teach your children - to be spiteful and childish because you feel insulted? Get over yourselves or get another job. Many of you are ex-military - you wouldn't get away with this silliness there so it's high time to stop acting like hurt childen. It's beneath you or it should be.

The "us versus them" mentality has never been worse.

This is quite a betrayal of public trust. They have shown they care little for their promise to the citizens of New York, "to protect and to serve" them. Self enrichment comes first, it seems.

If they care so little to serve an essential civic need, we should consider replacing them with those who will. Criminals won't take it easy just because the police is doing so. This is becoming a small national tragedy.

There are persuasive policy arguments for banning public sector unions. The NYPD showing why that makes sense.

They are angry at the tantrums police are throwing on their dime. I don't think anyone is scared of the "criminal element." Crime is at historic lows, the police are vastly overplaying their hand and it will cost them, but should bring change for the better.

First and foremost, as with any business, leadership starts at the top. And managers MUST be held responsible for the work of their charges when they have as direct a role as sergeants, lieutenants, and precinct captains.

Bratton MUST let these officers know that if their enlisted men and women do not get back to policing and UPHOLDING THE LAWS that they SWORE AN OATH to uphold, then the officers will bear the burden.

Watch how fast the Capt, LT, and Sarges tell their enlisted rank to get their butts in gear.

Second, EVERY officer who shirks his or her duty gets No More Overtime pay, no matter when it was banked. They lose out. Period. In fact, that money will be given to the officers who respected their command.

Reward good behaviors. It works.

Thirdly, I highly doubt that an officer who works in the quiet and safe precincts fears for his or her life when writing up a public urination charge.

Fourth, to the traffic agents: few people have ever liked what you do, sorry. I highly doubt many see you as a real threat and part of the cop problem.

And fifth, to all the cops that are turning your backs to the citizens that you work for: keeping digging yourselves a deeper and deeper hole from which you might never climb out of. You want our respect, EARN IT. Stop trying to pull 9/11 as the respect card. You want respect, then you give it to us. Until then, you look like a Whiney brat with a deadly weapon and immunity to most crimes and lawsuits.

Perhaps this will lead to a decline in crime. But if it doesn't, then here's the interesting question: if lack of policing leads to more people being murdered, can't we then clearly blame the police for those murders? Clearly they are actively inciting criminals to feel that they can act without consequence. Doesn't that therefore put blood on their hands in precisely the same way they claim it is on De Blasio's? And the point of this exercise would be what? To make the public hate them even more?

Bill Clinton said it in far fewer words.

It just depends what the meaning of "is" is.

Dangerous.

I listened to the Captain of the slain Officers on TV. He stated several time that "Civilians" this or that.

It is clear that this man, and I can only assume he speaks for thousands of NYC Police, thinks of himself as part of the group that constitutes NYC Citizens. But some other kind of group.

In this country we only have two kinds of Groups. Civilians and the Military.

Given such comments, coupled with the behavior of stopping doing their jobs, and the very public turning their backs on THE ELECTED REPRESENTITIVE OF THE PEOPLE, the Officers of NYC are heading down a dangerous path.

They are acting like a rebellious military. As such, they should be punished as such if they continue to behavior.

I do think they have very real complaints. But, as an arm of "The State" they must obey AND show respect for authority. If not, then they are no better than the kids in bad neighborhoods they complain about.
We have WAY too many cops. They have nothing to do but meet quotas and generate money. So what's the point? We need to freeze hiring and start the lay-offs. The city can make it's quota there.

There don't need to be layoffs. Thousands of officers resign from the  NYPD each year and NYPD has difficulty maintaining staffing levels. If you wanted to reduce the number of police officers you can just stop hiring replacements for the ones that quit.

With less work production, why not freeze hiring, overtime, promotions and begin looking at layoffs? Police may be aggrieved at the loss of two officers, and everyone sympathizes with them over this tragedy, but the fact remains that policing has to modernize, to change, to end improper deaths, to gain a new understanding of what is permitted and when. The complete failure to have representative policing that is more inclusive of all minorities plus the misplaced belief in some that they can shoot or even fatally restrain someone once an order is ignored have to end right now.
They need to be broken like Reagan did the Airline pilots!

Congratulations, NYPD officers-who-turn-your-backs: I now have no faith in you or in the NYPD.

I cannot trust that you would attempt to be of help to me in case of crime or crisis. Having seen your behavior twice now, it seems that your union is more important to you than your oath.

I believe that you can & may very well turn your backs again, or look the other way, when a citizen is in need.

"When a cop tells you to jump, you say how high"

THAT is the attitude we citizens of America and of NY protest against.

The NYPD, or ANY PD, is not my boss or my parent. They are paid by me and you and everyone else to uphold the laws. They are not being paid to be bullies.

Police work isn't for everyone issued a badge and a gun. Talk to a retired officer. Some have chosen the work as a career path for reasons that have nothing to do with policing as a passion. Some starting out this way may in time grow to love the job. But talk to a long retired officer from the days when the pay was lower and the risks higher and you will come to understand the ones who truly love policing, because it is in the blood passed down through a father or grandfather, would not be the ones now griping so publicly and so coarsely as some are now doing. I had an uncle who chose the work and never complained as hard as it got.

The behavior of NYC police demonstrates that reform of its abuses cannot possibly come from within. And it further indicates that NYC is hiring too many unsavory characters into the police department.

In my forty years living NYC the general regard for the police has never been lower, and deservedly so.
Strange, I'm a liberal and asked for non of that. Try fact checking next time.
